senses.definition: to give somebody an official warning after they have broken a rule

examples.x: The referee warned him for dangerous play.

senses.definition: to tell somebody to leave or stay away from a place or person, especially in a threatening way

examples.x: The farmer warned us off his land when we tried to camp there.

senses.definition: to advise somebody not to do something or to stop doing something

examples.x: She wanted to ask him about it but the look in his eyes warned her off.

senses.definition: used in questions to ask for particular information about somebody/something

examples.x: What is your name?
What (= what job) does he do?
What time is it?
What kind of music do you like?

senses.definition: the thing or things that; whatever

examples.x: What you need is a good meal.
Nobody knows what will happen next.

senses.definition: used to say that you think that something is especially good, bad, etc.

examples.x: What awful weather!
What a beautiful house!

senses.definition: to stay where you are or delay doing something until somebody/something comes or something happens wait

examples.x: She rang the bell and waited.

Have you been waiting long?
to wait (for) hours/days/weeks/months/years
I’ve been waiting (for) twenty minutes.
I'll wait outside until the meeting's over.
I had to wait in line at the bank.
Wait for me!
to wait for a bus
I'm still waiting for the results of my blood test.

examples.cf: wait for somebody/something to do something
examples.x: We're waiting for the rain to stop before we go out.
Hurry up! We're waiting to go.
We'll have to wait until it stops raining.
You'll just have to wait your turn (= wait until your turn comes).

senses.definition: to hope or watch for something to happen, especially for a long time

examples.x: Leeds United had waited for success for eighteen years.

examples.cf: wait for somebody/something to do something
examples.x: He's waiting for me to make a mistake.
I've been waiting a long time to say that to her.

senses.definition: to be ready for somebody to have or use

examples.x: Your car is waiting, sir.

senses.definition: to be left to be dealt with at a later time because immediate action is not needed

examples.x: I've got some calls to make but they can wait until tomorrow.

senses.definition: to receive something

examples.x: I got a call from Dave this morning.

senses.definition: to obtain something

examples.x: He has just got a new job.
I'll get the money somehow.
She opened the door wider to get a better look.

She really knows how to get results.

senses.definition: to buy something

examples.x: Where did you get that skirt?

Can I get a Coke?

Did you get your mother a present?
Why don't you get yourself a car?
$100 will get you the basic model.

senses.definition: to obtain or receive an amount of money by selling something

examples.x: If you sell it at auction you can expect to get roughly £800.

senses.definition: to go to a place and bring somebody/something back

examples.x: Quick—go and get a cloth!

senses.definition: to achieve or be given a particular mark or grade in an exam

examples.x: He got a ‘C’ in Chemistry and a ‘B’ in English.

senses.definition: to start to develop an illness; to suffer from a pain, etc.

examples.x: I got this cold off (= from) you!

senses.definition: to receive something as a punishment

examples.x: He got ten years (= was sent to prison for ten years) for armed robbery.

senses.definition: to connect to the internet or a phone network; to receive broadcasts from a particular television or radio station

examples.x: 95 per cent of the UK can now get superfast broadband.

senses.definition: to be connected with somebody by phone

examples.x: I wanted to speak to the manager but I got her assistant instead.

senses.definition: to arrive at or reach a place or point

examples.x: We got to San Diego at 7 o'clock.

Wait till we get home.

senses.definition: to move to or from a particular place or in a particular direction, sometimes with difficulty; to make somebody/something do this

examples.x: The bridge was destroyed so we couldn't get across the river.

senses.definition: to use a bus, taxi, plane, etc.

examples.x: We're going to be late—let's get a taxi.

senses.definition: to reach a particular state or condition; to make somebody/something/yourself reach a particular state or condition

to get better/worse

to get dressed/undressed (= to put your clothes on/take your clothes off)

My car got (= was) stolen at the weekend.

senses.definition: to reach the point at which you feel, know, are, etc. something

examples.x: After a time you get to realize that these things don't matter.

senses.definition: to start doing something

senses.definition: to have the opportunity to do something

senses.definition: to prepare a meal

examples.x: Who's getting the lunch?

I must go home and get tea for the kids.

senses.definition: to answer the phone or a door when somebody calls, knocks, etc.

examples.x: Will you get the door?

senses.definition: to catch or take hold of somebody, especially in order to harm or punish them

to get somebody by the arm/wrist/throat

senses.definition: to hit or wound somebody

examples.x: The bullet got him in the neck.

senses.definition: to understand somebody/something understand

examples.x: I don't get you.

I don't get it—why would she do a thing like that?

senses.definition: used to say that something happens or exists

examples.x: You get (= There are) all these kids hanging around in the street.

senses.definition: to make somebody feel confused because they do not understand something

examples.x: ‘What's the capital of Bhutan?’ ‘You've got me there!’ (= I don't know)

senses.definition: to annoy somebody Get

examples.x: What gets me is having to do the same thing all day long.

senses.definition: to speak or tell somebody something, using words said

examples.x: ‘Hello!’ she said.
‘That was marvellous,’ said Daniel.

senses.definition: to repeat words, phrases, etc.

examples.x: to say a prayer

senses.definition: to give particular information or instructions

senses.definition: to express an opinion on something

examples.x: His angry glance said it all.

to be worth a bomb/packet/fortune (= a lot of money)

senses.definition: used to recommend the action mentioned because you think it may be useful, pleasant, etc.

senses.definition: important, good or pleasant enough to make somebody feel satisfied, especially when difficulty or effort is involved

senses.definition: having money and possessions of a particular value

senses.definition: used to give advice

senses.definition: to have learned a skill or language and be able to use it

examples.cf: be known as somebody/something to somebody

senses.definition: to be able to recognize somebody/something identify

senses.definition: to understand the difference between one person or thing and another

senses.definition: to have seen, heard or experienced something

senses.definition: to speak or tell somebody something, using words said

senses.definition: to repeat words, phrases, etc.

examples.x: to say a prayer
Try to say that line with more conviction.

senses.definition: to give particular information or instructions

examples.x: The notice said ‘Keep Out’.
The clock said three o'clock.
The instructions say (that) we should leave it to set for four hours.
The book doesn't say where he was born.
The guidebook says to turn left.

senses.definition: to express an opinion on something

examples.x: Say what you like (= although you disagree) about her, she's a fine singer.

Anna thinks I'm lazy—what do you say (= what is your opinion)?

I say (= suggest) we go without them.
I wouldn't say they were rich (= in my opinion they are not rich).

It's difficult to say whether the story is true.
‘When will it be finished?’ ‘I couldn't say (= I don't know).’
Is it worth it? I would say not.

senses.definition: to make thoughts, feelings, etc. clear to somebody by using words, looks, movements, etc.

examples.x: His angry glance said it all.
Just what is the artist trying to say in her work?
The museum's architects have managed to say something about our national story.

senses.definition: to show, sometimes indirectly, what somebody/something is like

examples.x: That says it all really, doesn't it? (= it shows clearly what is true)
The incident says an awful lot about his character.
This says to me that there is more here than you are letting on.

senses.definition: to suggest or give something as an example or a possibility

examples.x: You could learn the basics in, let's say, three months.
Let’s take any writer, say (= for example) Dickens…
Say you lose your job: what would you do then?
